references: Table 1 illustrates the properties of our proposed method and provides a comparison between our algorithm and underlying analysis with related seminal works. As shown in this table, building upon the results in [17, 13], we extend the capability of FL to staleness. Table 1 also contains the convergence results for our proposed algorithm, which we will discuss in more details in Section 4.

The proof of this theorem can be found in Appendix B.
Theorem 2 shows a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„2T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±2â€‹Ïƒg2b)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘‡ğ’ªsuperscriptğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘”2ğ‘\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\tau^{2}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) for PersA-FL algorithm under MAML setup. Now, let us compare this rate with the convergence rate of FedAsync and Per-FedAvg, as in Table 1. The last term in the above rate, i.e., ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±2â€‹Ïƒg2b)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘”2ğ‘\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) accounts for personalization with biased gradient estimation. Moreover, compared to Per-FedAvg, the second term of this rate is different, which accounts for the maximum delay in asynchronous updates.
